title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 12
author: Various
snippet: [Footnote 1: A case of this kind occurred also in or near the town ofDundee in Scotland, where the glass was limited to the sameregions--below the lumbars.]

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 12
author: Various
snippet: Amongst those who preferred the risk of hanging in their own country, tothe certainty of starvation in a foreign one, was Reginald, or, as hewas usually called, Ranald Grahame of Inshannock--a gentleman who wasdistantly connected with the Viscounts of Dundee.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 12

snippet: Amongst those who preferred the risk of hanging in their own country, tothe certainty of starvation in a foreign one, was Reginald, or, as hewas usually called, Ranald Grahame of Inshannock--a gentleman who wasdistantly connected with the Viscounts of Dundee.

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: His first journey toDundee, the town where the regiment was quartered, undeceived himin his original supposition, but opened to him a new field ofaction.

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: From this fellow they learned that some time afterWaverley had gone from the headquarters of the regiment, a pedlar,called Ruthven, Rufnn, or Rivane, known among the soldiers by thename of Wily Will, had made frequent visits to the town of Dundee.

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Stern son of Lord Kenneth, high chief of Kintail,    Let the stag in thy standard bound wild in the gale!    May the race of Clan Gillean, the fearless and free,    Remember Glenlivat, Harlaw, and Dundee!

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I ought to have said that Edward, when he sent to Dundee for thebooks before mentioned, had applied for, and received permission,extending his leave of absence.

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But once again ye are most heartily welcome to mypoor house of Tully-Veolan! Hie to the house, Rose, and see thatAlexander Saunderson looks out the old Chateau Margaux, which Isent from Bourdeaux to Dundee in the year 1713.'

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: After a shortvisit to London, he proceeded on horseback, then the general modeof travelling, to Edinburgh, and from thence to Dundee, a seaporton the eastern coast of Angus-shire, where his regiment was thenquartered.

title: Waverley; Or 'Tis Sixty Years Since - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: And, in short,that Edward was now (the intermediate steps of cornet andlieutenant being overleapt with great agility) Captain Waverley,of Gardiner's regiment of dragoons, which he must join in theirquarters at Dundee in Scotland, in the course of a month.
